Users, initially we were going to make this kind of like as hard to install as we possibly could.

the administrator just has to unlock things in order to get access to the internet and everything so that it's more security.
Intended uses, things like, you know, human rights activists and stuff like that.

hey, why don't we start with something else?

their documentation was up to date.

just, you know, bragging rights.

Basically on the trusted path when essentially what it does is in the kernel and enforcing.
in the kernel that enforces that when you run an executable, it has to be owned by root.
It has to not be world or group writable. It has to be in a directory owned by roots that
is not world or group writable. And this applies even to root. That way as someone gets on your
box and puts some code in there and for some reason you've altered your path to actually execute
from your current directory first, for example, which would be stupid. But if you did that,
the thing has to be owned by route.
whole idea is that if someone pops an account on the system, then they're going to have to,
they're going to have to get routes to get their executable to run.

Debian, I think, if I remember correctly, requires that you actually.
actually physically meet someone in order to get your key signed and everything.
There's a lot of us that just really frightens us.

that Debian wanted. The latest Debian list, the mailing list archive that I saw
was that they decided that by default, BAS should not clear the screen upon logout.

it doesn't hurt. You know, if they don't know what they're doing when they leave and they leave
